text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of a building.
Every morning he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
When he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and walks up the stairs to reach his apartment on the 10th floor.
However, on rainy days and when there are other people in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor.

Why does he normally get off on the 7th floor? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out why the man normally gets off on the 7th floor when he takes the elevator in the evening.
Let's break this down step by step.
First, the man lives on the 10th floor.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor, which is the 1st floor.
That makes sense because he's going to work.
In the evening, he takes the elevator up to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs to reach his apartment on the 10th floor.
But on rainy days or when there are other people in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor.

So, why does he usually stop at the 7th floor otherwise?

Hmm, maybe it's something to do with the elevator's behavior.
If he always went directly to the 10th floor every evening, the elevator might not stop at the 7th floor when he needs it.

So, by getting off at the 7th floor on normal days, he's ensuring that the elevator will stop there when he needs it, especially on rainy days when he might not want to walk all the way up the stairs.

Wait, but why the 7th floor specifically? Why not the 5th or the 8th? Maybe the 7th floor is a common stopping point for the elevator, or perhaps it's a floor where he can easily walk up the stairs to his apartment.
Also, if the elevator is going to the 10th floor, stopping at the 7th floor on the way up makes sense because the elevator usually goes from the ground floor up, stopping at various floors.
So, if he gets off at the 7th floor, the elevator continues to the 10th, which is higher, so that works.

But then, why wouldn't he just go all the way up to the 10th floor normally? Maybe because when there are other people in the elevator, he doesn't want to wait for them to get off at higher floors, so he gets off earlier to avoid delays.
Or perhaps on rainy days, he wants to avoid walking up the stairs, so he takes the elevator as far as possible, which is the 7th floor, and then walks up.
Wait, but the problem says that on rainy days and when there are other people in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor.
So, normally, he doesn't go all the way, but on those days, he does.
That suggests that on normal days without rain or people, he stops at the 7th floor.

So, why does he do that?

Maybe it's because when he takes the elevator down in the morning, he doesn't have to wait for it to stop at the 7th floor on the way down.
But in the evening, if he takes the elevator up, he can get off at the 7th floor, which is closer to his apartment, and then walk up the stairs.
But if the elevator is full or it's raining, he doesn't want to walk, so he takes the elevator all the way.
Alternatively, perhaps the elevator only stops at certain floors, like every 5 floors or something, so the 7th floor is a convenient stopping point.

Or maybe the building's elevator doesn't go all the way to the 10th floor unless someone requests it, so by getting off at the 7th floor, he ensures that the elevator will continue up to the 10th floor when needed.

I think the key here is that by getting off at the 7th floor on normal days, he's conditioning the elevator to stop there, so that when he needs it on rainy days or when there are other people, the elevator will stop at the 7th floor and take him all the way up.
If he never got off there, the elevator might not stop at the 7th floor on the way up, making it inconvenient on rainy days.

So, in summary, the man stops at the 7th floor normally because he wants the elevator to remember to stop there, ensuring that on rainy days or when the elevator is busy, he can get off there and then walk up the stairs.
If he always took the elevator all the way, the elevator might not stop at the 7th floor, making it harder for him to get there when needed.

</think>

The man stops at the 7th floor because by doing so, he ensures the elevator will later pass the 7th floor on its upward journey.
This allows him to get off there on rainy days or when the elevator is busy, then walk up the stairs to his 10th-floor apartment.
If he didn't get off at the 7th floor normally, the elevator might not stop there, making it harder for him to reach his apartment when needed.
